how would you describe your main use cas: Note-taking;Producing/publishing interactive fiction;Worldbuilding (e.g. for role-playing games);Other
as you selected other: what are other pr: Searchable & filterable repositories of images (mine or others); personal websites (in the spirit of Geocities)
do you share your tiddlywiki(s) with oth: Yes, and I am the only editor/administrator of my wiki(s)
putting it all together, what value does: It is the primary way I present most of my creative projects in an interactive medium, for organizing large collections of images otherwise difficult to do elsewhere, and for generally being extremely flexible and customizable to hyper-specific needs. It changed everything.
what is your level of ability with tiddl: I have customised TiddlyWiki through options and plugins;I am comfortable using WikiText widgets (e.g. <$transclude>, <$list>...);I am comfortable writing filter expressions;I have written custom HTML;I have written custom CSS styles;I have written custom JavaScript
how do you save changes in tiddlywiki?: Single-file wiki with custom saver (e.g. TiddlyPWA, Timimi, tw5-browser-nativesaver);Single-file wiki with TiddlyDesktop
how do you back up/sync changes between: TiddlySpot / TiddlyHost;Neocities, Nekoweb, tiiny.host, omg.lol and similar services

outside of plugins, palettes and other i: Far too many to be exhaustive within the limit, but it includes stylesheets, macros, ViewTemplates, and core edits. I often use & modify community ones (themes, plugins, solutions). I have very rarely made simple JavaScript functions when WikiText equivalents were not possible.
what are we doing well? prompts for thin:
- Uses familiar languages like CSS and HTML, giving a hands-on environment to learn both.
- The community is incredibly warm and friendly towards beginners, making it a great atmosphere to learn.
- The openness of sharing and building on solutions.
- The commitment to backwards compatibility meaning community solutions are almost always evergreen, even a decade later.
- The sky is the limit with what you can create. It is anything you want it to be, if you put your mind to it.
what could we do better? prompts for thi:
- I am wary of generative AI. My relationship with TW would change if it was officially incorporated (core plugins, etc).
- Multi-user solutions are technically possible to DIY as a novice programmer, but impossible to make fully usable. It is my only lasting problem with TW because it means I can rarely use this powerful software in collaborative projects, or teach it to others hands-on. An *easy to use* solution for multi-users that can handle conflicting edits would be my dream come true!
with your consent, we would like to publ: Yes, I am happy for my responses to be published
